G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ��������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������, this Court "may from time to time, upon a complaint after a divorce, revise and alter its judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children" upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u.proposition: The Bristol County Probate and Family Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, �����������������������������������������������������������������������������������, G.L. c. 215, �����������������������������������������������������������������������������������, and, to the extent applicable, G.L. c. 209C, �����������������������������������������������������������������������������������, as this matter concerns custody and parenting time of minor children of parents subject to this Courts prior orders.

G.L. c. 215, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: The same principles apply to modifications of prior custody orders regardless of whether the original proceeding was a divorce, separation, or related custody action, as the Probate and Family Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������, § 6.

G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: The requested modification is also consistent with the factors enumerated in G.L. c. 208, ����������������������������������������������������������������, § 31, including: the past and present living arrangements of the Children; the relationship of the Children with each parent; each parents willingness to encourage a positive relationship with the other parent; and the Childrens physical, emotional, and developmental needs.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, �����������������������������������������������������������������������������������, this Court "may from time to time, upon a complaint after a divorce, revise and alter its judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children" upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the children.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald deals with G.L. c. 209C (the paternity statute) and relocation/visitation issues where the mother of a nonmarital child is the sole legal parent prior to an adjudication of paternity. It does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 208, nor does it discuss post‑divorce modification standards, material and substantial change in circumstances, or the best interests test under c. 208. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition about a court’s power under G.L. c. 208 to revise and alter judgments after divorce concerning minor children.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: This appeal arises, as the court rightly concludes, because the judge impermissibly ruled, for reasons that were irrelevant under the paternity statute, G. L. c. 209C, that the mother needed the court’s or the putative father’s permission before she could relocate with the child to New York. ... After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a) ... .

Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and a determination that modification is in the best interests of the children.
Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the Probate Court’s continuing jurisdiction to modify custody orders in divorce cases and emphasizes that custody decrees are interlocutory and may be changed upon “good cause shown.” However, it does not articulate or apply the specific “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” standard; nor does it frame the test expressly as a two‑part inquiry requiring both changed circumstances and best interests. Instead, the court focuses broadly on the welfare of the child as the controlling principle. Therefore, it does not support the precise proposition claimed.
Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).relevant_excerpt: “Orders as to custody of children in the cases arising under these sections are not final in the sense that a judgment in a proceeding at law or a final decree in a suit in equity is final and not subject to subsequent change by the court. They are in their nature interlocutory and subject to modification at any future time during the lives of the parents and the minority of the children upon good cause shown. … The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody determination is the best interests of the children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly situates this case within the longstanding Massachusetts rule that custody determinations turn on the best interests of the child, and it quotes prior authority describing the best interests of the children as the ‘paramount concern.’ The court reaffirms that G.L. c. 209C § 10(a) authorizes awards of custody ‘as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child’ and treats that standard as the governing, overarching consideration in custody decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody determination is the best interests of the children.
Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in these types of proceedings the governing standard is the child’s best interests, and later emphasizes that Massachusetts jurisprudence has always made the interest of the child paramount in such matters. Although this is an adoption/termination case rather than a generic custody dispute, the court’s language confirms that the paramount consideration in determining a child’s placement (including custody-like determinations in adoption) is the child’s best interests.
Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “Each day judges must grapple with the consequences of significant relationships that develop between young children and the adults in whose care or custody they are placed. It is for that reason that our jurisprudence has always made the interest of the child paramount.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has recognized that stability, continuity of care, and a parents willingness and ability to foster the childs relationship with the other parent are key factors in assessing the childs best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child when determining custody and best interests. While the Court notes factors such as the child’s bond with the father, his doing well in school, and the father’s involvement, it does not expressly articulate a doctrinal rule that stability, continuity of care, and a parent’s willingness and ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent are key best‑interests factors. Those concepts appear only implicitly, not as a recognized, stated standard.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The judge found that Vaughn “is doing well at school. His guidance counsellor is hopeful he will continue to shine in school as he did during his last marking period.” … “[Ross] for some five to six years has been [Vaughn’s] primary care giver. He has been responsible for most of the cooking, shopping and caring for [Vaughn], [Vaughn] has been his main involvement, while the mother has been significantly involved in her real estate career.” (These findings are discussed, but not framed as a general legal rule about stability or fostering the other parent’s relationship.)

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has recognized that stability, continuity of care, and a parents willingness and ability to foster the childs relationship with the other parent are key factors in assessing the childs best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition attributes recognition of specific best-interest factors (stability, continuity of care, and fostering the child’s relationship with the other parent) to the Supreme Judicial Court, but this case is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision, not an SJC opinion. While the case does discuss primary nurturing parent, primary caretaker, and minimizing disruption—concepts related to stability and continuity—it does not articulate the broader triad of factors stated in the proposition, nor does it frame them as SJC-recognized criteria. Thus it does not provide direct authority for the claimed SJC proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Signorelli v. Albano, 21 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Signorelli v. Albano, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 939 (1985)
Signorelli v. Albano, 21 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Defendants repeated disparaging comments about the Plaintiff to the Children and his practice of blaming the Plaintiff for missed activities, particularly where those activities are scheduled unilaterally during the Plaintiffs time, undermine the Childrens secure relationship with the Plaintiff and expose them to adult conflict, contrary to their best interests.
Signorelli v. Albano, 21 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute and the application of the Yannas “real advantage” standard. It does not discuss disparaging comments by a parent, blaming the other parent for missed activities, or exposing children to adult conflict. The only behavioral discussion is a brief, generalized note that each parent looked for faults in the other’s child‑raising abilities; there is no holding or reasoning about disparagement of a parent to children or its impact on their best interests.
Signorelli v. Albano, 21 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “An examination of the lengthy transcript in this case indicates that each parent, because of the importance of continuing his or her warm relationship with the child, was led to look for faults in the other’s child-raising abilities. It is clear from the record, as the judge found, that both have much to offer this child. It may be that both will recognize that continued litigation on these matters might embitter the relationships and that for all parties the best solution is one reached by the parents themselves.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The Defendants repeated disparaging comments about the Plaintiff to the Children and his practice of blaming the Plaintiff for missed activities, particularly where those activities are scheduled unilaterally during the Plaintiffs time, undermine the Childrens secure relationship with the Plaintiff and expose them to adult conflict, contrary to their best interests.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether separating identical twin siblings between two parents is in their best interests and criticizes the judge’s excessive reliance on the children’s stated preferences. It does not discuss a parent’s disparaging comments about the other parent, blaming the other parent for missed activities, or how such conduct undermines the children’s secure relationship or exposes them to adult conflict. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “We have examined both the record from the proceedings below and the judge’s notes from his private interview with Rebecca and find no evidence from which the judge properly could have concluded that a split physical custody arrangement would be in the childrens’ best interests. Indeed, the evidence — including the opinions and recommendations of various witnesses (expert and nonexpert alike) plus the twins’ own reported statements about being separated from each other — is to the contrary.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that persistent interference with a childs relationship with the other parent, or behavior that places the child in the middle of conflict and loyalty tensions, may warrant modification of custody.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation and modification standards under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, and focuses on whether there was a material and substantial change in circumstances and whether the mother had a good, sincere reason to move. It does not discuss persistent interference with the child’s relationship with the other parent, or conduct placing the child in the middle of conflict or loyalty tensions, as a basis for modifying custody. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: "A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’"

Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that persistent interference with a childs relationship with the other parent, or behavior that places the child in the middle of conflict and loyalty tensions, may warrant modification of custody.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a care-and-protection proceeding and evaluates parental unfitness based on serious psychological differences between mother and child, the mother’s refusal to seek counseling, and the child’s strong attachment to foster parents. It does not discuss one parent’s interference with the child’s relationship with the *other* parent, nor placing the child in loyalty conflicts between two parents, nor custody modification between parents. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about interference with the child’s relationship with the other parent as a basis for custody modification.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “(4) That there are serious psychological differences between [Mrs. F] and her son Dom. (5) That [Mrs. F] refuses to recognize these differences and has consistently and persistently refused to take steps to correct them. (6) That these differences have prevented [Dom] from receiving sound and normal physical, mental, moral and educational development. (7) The passage of time has created a psychological bond between Dom and his foster parents… (8) To remove him from his foster parents at this time would have serious deleterious effects on Dom.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, �����������������������������������������������������������������������������������, this Court "may from time to time, upon a complaint after a divorce, revise and alter its judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children" upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the children.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a post‑divorce modification case under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (or related custody‑modification statute). While the court repeatedly states that removal may be ordered only when it is in the children’s best interests, it does not discuss the statutory authority to ‘revise and alter its judgment’ on complaint after divorce, nor does it frame its analysis in terms of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The same principles apply to modifications of prior custody orders regardless of whether the original proceeding was a divorce, separation, or related custody action, as the Probate and Family Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, ���������������������������������������������������������������, § 6.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion does state that a petition to modify a divorce judgment (here, visitation/custody-related) is governed by the Schuler/Robbins/Hinds standard requiring a material change of circumstances, but it does not discuss or even cite G.L. c. 215, § 6, nor does it expressly address whether the same principles apply regardless of whether the original custody order arose from divorce, separation, or another custody proceeding. Its focus is on the evidentiary standard for modifying visitation in a divorce case, not on the scope of the Probate and Family Court’s broad equitable powers across different types of custody actions.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “We apply the words of Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981), a case seeking modification of alimony and child support provisions in a divorce judgment, to the present case, also demanding modification of a divorce judgment, although as to a different subject matter: ‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’”

Bouchard v. DeGagne, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Bouchard v. DeGagne, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 100 (2016)
Bouchard v. DeGagne, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: The same principles apply to modifications of prior custody orders regardless of whether the original proceeding was a divorce, separation, or related custody action, as the Probate and Family Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6.
Bouchard v. DeGagne, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a criminal law / search-and-seizure decision dealing with informant veracity and the exclusionary rule, not family law or custody. It does not discuss G.L. c. 215, § 6, Probate and Family Court jurisdiction, or standards for modifying custody orders from divorce, separation, or related custody actions. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about custody modification principles and Probate and Family Court equitable powers.
Bouchard v. DeGagne, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of custody, divorce, separation, related custody actions, or G.L. c. 215, § 6. It is focused entirely on probable cause, confidential informants, and the exclusionary rule in a criminal prosecution.

M.P. v. C.P., 87 Mass. App. Ct. 462 (201.raw_text: M.P. v. C.P., 87 Mass. App. Ct. 462 (2015)
M.P. v. C.P., 87 Mass. App. Ct. 462 (201.proposition: In assessing whether joint legal custody remains appropriate, the Court considers the parents ability to communicate and cooperate regarding major decisions affecting the children. Where the level of conflict or lack of cooperation undermines effective shared decision-making, modification is appropriate.
M.P. v. C.P., 87 Mass. App. Ct. 462 (201.case_name: Nantasket Beachfront Condominiums, LLC v. Hull Redevelopment Authority
M.P. v. C.P., 87 Mass. App. Ct. 462 (201.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision about a land disposition agreement and contract/liquidated damages issues between a developer and a redevelopment authority. It does not concern custody, family law, or parental decision-making, and nowhere discusses joint legal custody, parents’ communication, or modification of custody orders. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the stated proposition regarding joint legal custody and parental cooperation.
M.P. v. C.P., 87 Mass. App. Ct. 462 (201.relevant_excerpt: For purposes of resolving Nantasket’s contract-based claims, it is important to keep in mind that it is the authority that was the party to the LDA, not individual board members. Municipal redevelopment authorities are liable in contract and tort “in the same manner as ... private corporation[s],” and their officers and agents are, in the same fashion as those of private corporations, generally not personally liable in tort or contract. G. L. c. 121B, § 13, inserted by St. 1969, c. 751, § 1.
